comments:
I have a report which has 4 charts and a table. This report is generated 
based on the data returned from the warehouse. While the ETL process runs 
and the CPU consumption is over 50% and memory usage is about 30%, the 
report gives NullPointerException. The stack trace is of the excepton is 
given below.

N.B.- The machine used for deployment is a linux box having 5 GB RAM.

Created an attachment (id=50137)
Report design file
Can you please also upload chart.rptlibrary? Thanks.

It seems the root cause of the issue is deadlock/timeout on the db2 database.
Manually executing the same sql that the report uses, throws the following SQL
error

SQL0911N The current transaction has been rolled back because of a deadlock
or timeout. Reason code "68". SQLSTATE=40001
--Is there any way to suppress this exception ?

SQL querys seem very complicated. Maybe you can run sql query first on db2 to make sure they are correct.

If they are correct, next step is to use sql querys in BIRT. Let's see whether there are other issues for the case.

The sql querys are correct bcoz they are working fine now..

Before the transaction has been rolled back because of a deadlock
or timeout. Reason code "68". SQLSTATE=40001
NullPointerException should be avoided. Reassign to Chart.
The NPE is already caught and just shows in log. Also the issue is not reproducible on my machine.
Did Bora's comment says that this issue has been resolved?

The issue is resolved for me.
But I wanted to know that when the query gets fired and it does not get access to the tables bcoz there is a lock on the table, it gives the mentioned exception. SO, Is there any way to suppress it?
Reassign to data team to answer comment#12

(In reply to comment #12)
> The issue is resolved for me.
> But I wanted to know that when the query gets fired and it does not get access
> to the tables bcoz there is a lock on the table, it gives the mentioned
> exception. SO, Is there any way to suppress it?
> 
We do not have a mechanism to suppress Exceptions.

From Data Team's perspective, we should suppress no SQL Exceptions, unless that Exception is expected. It is apparently that the SQL Exceptions mentioned in the bug report is not the one that is expected so we will simply throw it to DtE's client, that is, engine.

And I have talked to engine team, they also do not have mechanism to suppress the exception.

Re-assign to chart to finish up the bug.
Marked bug as invalid, since this exception needs to be reported by the data engine.
